title: Will Joe Biden's running mate matter for the 2020 presidential election? - Quora
tags: Political Campaigns in the United States of America

response.answer_text: I think Biden’s choice will make a marginal difference. If picking the right VP means a 3% gain for Biden on Election Day, he would be wise to make the right choice. Biden’s got to pick a woman. That one’s a no-brainer. If Biden were to pick a man, and then Trump showed his characteristic loyalty by ejecting Pence and bringing on Ambassador Haley, Trump could expect a minimum of a 5-point gain. As a woman of color, Haley would greatly enhance Trump’s portfolio as VP. This would be enough to hold onto enough of the states he won in 2016 to secure him a second term. Biden can’t take that chance. He has to pick a Democrat who offers the right blend of qualities. Elizabeth Warren would be a good choice for cementing the loyalties of the progressive wing of the party. It would also scare the centrist Republicans who have been thinking of supporting Biden. Warren and Sanders both have been saying that their supporters must get behind Biden. Any progressive who failed to turn out in 2016 because they felt sore about Sanders not getting the nomination knows how that works out. Only the phenomenally stupid and/or pig-headed among progressives will fail to turn out for Biden on 2020. I’m not sure Biden needs to pick Warren to bring in their votes. Also, Warren is needed right where she is in the Senate. Also, she’s white. Picking her doesn’t exactly send the big tent message the Democrats want to send. Amy Klobuchar is a reasonable choice. She’s a centrist, and she’s strong in the Midwest. She’s reasonably honest and reasonably competent. She seems like a good choice. I think she’d make a good first women POTUS, if Biden age were to become an issue in two years. But she’s white, too. Again, the campaign probably ought not to pick a white person for VP. In order for the Democrats’ selection of an old white man not to upset their big tent message, I think Biden has to choose a non-white woman. I said this last year at this time, and I stick by that idea. In particular, Democrats can’t keep reaching out to the black community for solid support without offering something concrete in return. It’s great that Obama served two terms. He’s just one POTUS. Picking one of the two black women from among the top tier of candidates for VPOTUS is the way to go—especially given recent events. Abrams is a good choice. She has experience, and we’ve heard her name before. She’s a fighter with a good cause. I like her. I respect her. But the top choice has to be Kamala Harris. Harris has a prosecutor’s background. She’s a solid centrist. She won’t scare centrist Republicans who are trying to justify to themselves either not voting in November or actually pulling the metaphorical lever for the Democrats. She has experience at the federal level. She’s not a yes [wo]man who will tell Biden whatever he wants to hear. We know they have differences of opinion. That’s needed. It’s also in keeping with the way Democrats govern. Whereas arguably Abrams ought to be kept in Georgia fighting the good fight there, California has a raft of Democrats who can be sent to the US Senate to replace Harris. If Biden’s health becomes an issue two years in, Harris would make a very respectable first woman POTUS. It has to be her in order for Biden to maximize whatever advantage a good VPOTUS pick can bring.

If you think running mates don’t matter, you’re ignorant of history. Bill Clinton made an unconventional choice of running mate in 1992, choosing a fellow Southerner rather than “balancing the ticket” with someone from a different region, but that choice reassured many of us that he was a bit smarter than GHWB, who had picked Dan Quayle to pander to the religious right four years previous. Swing voters - those more interested in good government than ideological/religious purity - can easily be tipped one way or the other by simply imagining what has happened seven times in our nation’s history: the Vice President taking over due to the President’s death. Those indifferent between Bush and Clinton could decide based on the “pucker factor” - can you imagine President Quayle? For more definitive proof, I give you Sarah Palin. McCain “had to pick a woman”, according to the pundits. I called BS then, and Obama did, too. Trump learned from McCain’s mistake, and chose his polar opposite (qualified, disciplined, and reassuring to the Evangelical wing of the Party), while Clinton went for non-threatening (and uninspiring) - and the results speak for themselves. Biden needs to choose a successor whom voters will recognize as ready to take over on day one. Choosing based on geography, gender, or race is a losing strategy.
